Hi Ken,

Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> Colin, thanks very much for all the info.  I have to congratulate 
> you on making SharpNEAT such a great system.  It's incredibly fast, 
> has a nice GUI, and implements an efficient version of NEAT.

Thanks!

>   Some 
> of my students are now choosing to use it inside their projects.
>   

That's great news. It's really nice to know that people are using the 
code in an educational setting and learning from using and reading the code.


> The next version sounds exciting and I'll be looking forward to it.
>   


Don't hold your breath on that one but maybe in the new year or early 
next year. It's mostly there but I've been taking the opportunity to 
rethink some areas of the code. E.g. I've code in the default NEAT 
evolution algorithm to try and keep the number of species far more 
tightly controlled than the current method of adjusting the speciation 
threshold does. I don;t think you can ever absolutely clamp the number 
of species to a specific number because the population may not have 
enough (or any) variation to give the precise number of species you 
want, so I came up with a halfway solution that I think makes sense. 
There are a few other little tweaks I've made, unfortunately this is all 
tons of code I've written that hasn't actually been tested or even 
executed yet which is a /bit/ of a worry.

While I'm here, have you (or anyone else on the list) had any thoughts 
or made any further developments on your "Patterns without development" 
paper/idea? It certainly seems like a really powerful approach/concept 
but formulating a method that utilises it could be tricky, e.g. a method 
of converting the generated patterns into neural nets.

Colin.
